text:
Hazed golden. Aroma has died over the years (a bit of cardboard). Dulled down sweetness, mostly malty.

Notes: Bottle was ~ 6 yrs old, opened for Erics bottle share, Dec 16
2007 Vintage. 22oz bottle. Poured a golden color with an averaged sized head. Grains, toasted bread, some fruitiness, and some stale grass.

Nice golden color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of caramel malt, hops, some citrus, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, hops, caramel, fruit, and spice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Good stuff.
22 ounce bottle. Thanks John! Pours a cloudy light gold with a very nice beige head. Aroma of malt, fruit, grass, and caramel. Taste is similar. Very well made, very nice to drink.
Yellow pour with a white head. The aroma has some bread notes and not too much else. The flavor is full of biscuit malt, bready malt, grass and toffee. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bomber thanks to Phatdog1. Poured an unfiltered yellow color with a frothy white top and lacing action. Taste of sweet malts, honey, apple juice, caramel, and honey flavors. Fizzy, foamy, medium-high carbonation. All hail Smuttynose!
(22oz bomber) cloudy yellow, fine white bubbles. Nose of citrus fruit, kumquat, bit of honey, funky. Taste of burnt grain, honey, rose, raw grain, medium richness, burnt caramel.

bomber courtesy of phatdog1; thanks Craig!  nice amber orange hazy pour.  aroma is malt with some citrus (orange) and slight alcohol - nice combo!  nice med. palate.  Taste was balanced - a few things going on - malt sweetness (at times, a tad too sweet) + citrus sweetness; slight caramel; then slight drying hops at end; faintest bit of alcohol.  Really like this beer and brewery - I can see why this beer is at the top of this style!

2006 Bottle. Clear gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma is strong and sweet with some slight spice notes. Honey, floral, fruity. Flavor is fruity and sweet, bready, spicy. Touches of caramel, figs, apples, honey. This has definitely been taken over by the malty side after aging for 6 years, almost no bitterness/hop presence at all.

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy orange with nice white head that thins a bit too quickly and leaves great lacing. Smells of bread, butterscotch, hay, dough, and grass.  Taste is slightly sweet with a medium body, average carbonation and a short finish. Great brew!

Draft. Hazy orange. White head. Cold. Interesting. Good lacing. Not yeasty or malty. Not bland but don't know how to describe it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours with a hazy golden hued body with a medium sized, very slightly off-white head. Aromas are of tea, malt, medium sweet, stewed fruit, marmalade, mild oxidation, floral. Pretty clean yeast wise, but seems somewhat old. Flavors are hollow, bready, grainy, mild DMS, medium bitter with a very slightly bitter side of neutral balance. Moderate carbonation, dry, medium-low bodied. Im not sure if this is an old bottle or not, but it doesnt quite meet the expectations Ive had for this beer.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2013 Delicious beer. Lots of malt and spice flavors with a touch of banana. Really good.

22oz bottle, 2011 vintage. Sweet, bready malts, with a light pepper spice. Soft, smooth carbonation, dry texture. Some orange zest, something caramelly sweet, like a belgian waffle. Some floral hops; honey. Yellow orange color, becomes hazy with the sediment. Thin off-white head leaves decent lace. Sweet taste, with a good bit of light bitterness. Not cloying, pretty tasty. Sweet in the Belgian kind of way. Some banana. Only a light bit, if drunk too quickly. Very enjoyable and interesting brew. Better than expected.

Bottle shared by Lunch. Thanks for leaving half of the bottle for me even though I hit my threshold and fell asleep.

The beer is fairly hazy and light orange in color, with 1/2" of creamy, white head that leaves some good lacing on the glass. The aroma brings malt, light caramels, floral notes, and subtle spice. The flavor is malt forward, with a healthy floral presence, and caramel malt flavors. The finish brings some hop bitterness to round things out, though malt flavors take over once again, lingering on the palate between sips. Alcohol content is hidden well. The sweet nature of the style precludes me from wanting a second helping. Overall, a decent beer and a solid example of the style. Recommended.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-01-2011

Tap sample at Smuttynose brewery in April 2010. Amber colour with a fluffy white head. Sweetish on the palate. Plenty of chewy, quite fat, malt. Some caramel & toffee. Pretty well done but a bit too sweet for me. Bocks are not really my thing at the best of times.

Bottle from Beers of the World, cellar aged 4 years. Nose of honey, biscuits, nicely aged with a bit of oxidation. Decently bitter finish following rich, creamy, mellow malts flavor. Full and rich, and has aged very well.
Bottle; clear orange with medium beige head; aroma- caramel, spruce, floral, resin; taste-light sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, oily feel, average carbonation, mild bitter finish. Delicious

NCAA 2012
Aroma - Fruity
Appearance - Golden peach, slight haze, small but long-lasting head
Taste - Malty, 
Palate - Smooth but a little harsh finish
Overall - On the right day, I could really like this beer but it isnt hitting the spot today.
Good body. Not too much malt with good hops spice. At first slightly harsh bu then quite tasty and drinkable.
Bottle from 2008. Aged really well, with some beautiful rich malt notes coming through: cherry, caramel, toffee, and a touch of citrus and spice. Very drinkable.
This is not a maibock, should be changed to strong lager/imperial pils. Tastes like sugar, and not much else. A decent malt liquor.

Aroma: Low malt, no noticeable spicyness. No hops. Low fruity esters which may have contributed to the lack of malt aroma. No diacetyl.

Appearance: Large fizzy white head at first, but finished creamy. Light, hazy amber.

Flavor: Malt and hop were well balanced. Moderate hop, but well hidden due to the balanced nature of the beer. Alcohol was more noticeable on the finish. No noble spice from hops, slight DMS. Slight fruity esters.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, medium carbonation, alcohol noticeable on the finish.

Overall: Needs more malt aroma on aroma to match style.

Drank as a consolation beer after Ernesto987 broke the top of a bottle of FFF Gorch Fock which dropped glass shards into the beer.  This was a malty tripelesque lager with a very earthy hay like malt body and a light hopping.  Decent I suppose.

Soft citrus and yeast aroma. Thick two finger head. Creamy yellow haze. Sour tangy taste with some bitterness in the middle. Can sense a hint of alcohol warm down the throat.Clean finish and refreshing.
Big malty hopless lager. Its pretty rich in flavors. I think its alright. Not bad.

The aroma is grains, pale malt and slightly perfumed.  The flavor is similar to the aroma with a bit of alcohol in there.  Not my favorite style, this was good but similar to others in the style, I just dont care for bocks that use pale malt only.

Belle couleur dorée tirant doucement vers le orange brûlé. Au nez cest très semblable à un barleywine anglais avec des notes de sucre dorge. Ya vraiment quelque chose de typiquement Smuttynose dans son corps, robuste presque sirupeux mais extrêmement délicat sur la langue dû également à une effervescence parfaitement calibré. Même à 7.7%, je la déguste tranquillement comme une bière beaucoup plus grosse. Le profil malté est bien complété par une très légère morsure houblonnée.

Bottle. Light to moderate malt note of grain, light hebs and flowers for the hops, faint soap for the yeast, with apple, white wine, honey and a hint of medicine in the background. Head is large, frothy, white with fair lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is slightly hazy, light amber. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is on the lighter side of medium, and little slick with a lively carbonation and a lightly alcoholic finish. Although very light in aroma, the flavor is quite bold. A perfect to style Heller Bock.

I am developing a taste for this style. The aroma was citrus and heavy malt. Appearance as advertised; a hazy gold with white head that lasts and laces well. The taste was excellent, almost that of an English pale but far heavier - loved that it is not extra hopped or overly tampered. The palate leaves a distinct citrus flalvor but manages to mingle well with the malts. The carbonation is perfect. Not too bitter. Overall it is  a style I am new to but due to the recent trials with this type it is one I will continue to delve into.  This and the Rogue are keepers for sure..... but I nod to the Rogue

GABF 2011.  Hazy bright gold with a dense lasting white head.  Nice toffee forward aroma with biscuit and pale malt, a bit of sugary esters as well.  Biscuity pale malt flavor.  Full body, mild sweetness, but nothing much going on to me.

This poured a lighter orange color with a beige head. Aroma was sweet candy sugar, grassy hops, and some fruity notes too. Flavor was fruity, sweet, grainy and grassy, very refreshing but a tiny bit cloying, quite surprised by this one.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours hazy deep honey with big three or four inch white head.  Highly carbonated, some fluffy lacing, and medium/thick body.  Taste is acidic  floral malt, some citrus, and earthy/peppery hop finish.  Best maibock I have had, but the alcohol still peeks out.  Not that easy to drink, but lots of flavor.
(bottle) Dark gold with white head. Aroma of sweet malt. Flavor is sweet biscuit/honey malt with some alcohol and a spicy hops finish.
Cloudy yellow, thin white ring. Spicy aroma. fruity, sugary, spicy taste. Thick body. Sharp bite & finish. Not so easy on your "self".

22 oz. from Shaws. Wasnt sure what to expect since ive never had a maibock. Smells pretty awful (like bubblegum). Luckily it tastes fantastic. Big malt flavoe which tastes nothing like any lager Ive ever had. Definitely interesting.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark gold with a large, frothy white head, long retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy biscuit and honey malt with light hop notes and spicy, peppery alcohol at the end.  There are some light vanilla and fruity notes as well, though these are faint.  Flavor is moderate sweet malt with a balanced alcohol and hop bitterness.  The beer is very clean, with no off-flavors or aromas.  Palate is sweet and it dries out near the end.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

Pours a clear old gold with a 1 finger, sticky eggshell head. Huge grain, toast and white bread crust nose, a touch of caramel and hints of floral and spicy hops. Upon first sip it tastes like sweet grain, cereal, toast and caramel. Then the alcohol hits, you can tell its alcohol, but the "sweetness" of the alcohol seems to the most notable characteristic, light dark fruit notes (possibly fusel alcohol), along with some overripe banana. After the initial wave of alcohol it calms down a bit with a nice sweet grain, spicy hop finish. Palate is medium bodied, syrupy on entry, then immediately drying from the intense alcohol rush. Even though at first this beer was a bit like drinking a heavy lager with a shot of Irish Whiskey sitting at the bottom I wound up thoroughly enjoying it by the time I was done with my glass. Were I rating from a smaller sample size this would be getting a much lower rating. A bit hard to believe that this only has 7.7% alcohol though. I would think it was closer to 9-10%
(bottle)  Aquired in Portsmouth during 2011 New England vacation.

Bottle pours cloudy orange-amber with medium white head.  Aroma chiefly sweet malt and light fruit.  Taste huge malts and sweet corn with slight spice, bread, caramel.  Finish slight hops and sweetness.  Palate thick, slightly syrupy and a little oily.  Slight alcohol burn on the finish.
I like sweet beers but didnt find the sweetness particularly pleasant on this one.  Worth a try but wouldnt seek out.

pours hazy orange with a thick, lasting white head and minimal lacing.  aroma is sweet tropical fruit.  body is medium-full.  taste is dry with quite a bit of hop character as well crisp fruit notes.  finish is tart, dry and has a bit of a burn.  There is also considerably more residual yeast than I would have expected for a lager.

Bomber, bottled in 2011.  Pours clear orange with yellow, topped with a 3-finger fluffy white head.  Aromas of floral hops and flower petals, English malt, dough, berries, sugar, and candy.  The flavor is sweet and malty, with caramel, berry, light bittering hops, and alcohol.  Spicy, peppery aftertaste.  Medium carbonation and medium to full body, with a warming mouthfeel.  Really tasty.  A nice crisp summer beer that would be equally as good in autumn or winter. [733]

Bottle; pour is slightly hazy gold with a modest white head that retains on the average side. A slight nutty note on the nose; caramel, noble hops, really. Its fairly robust for the style; perhaps a bt overly sweet. Its quite nice overall.

22 oz. bomber.  It pours a bright golden orange with thick white head.  The aroma is of baked bread, crackers, sweet malt.  I also get notes of mild citrus and some light spice.  The flavor is mildly sweet with notes of caramel, honey, bread.  The focus shifts to a light spicy hop twang.   It has a medium, creamy body and finishes crisp.  This is enjoyable.  This is a pretty good take on the style from Smuttynose.

Pretty, grows into a beautiful transparent gold-orange, forming a fearless, fluffy head.  Smells, if not good, then interesting.  Winelike tartness mixes with bubblegum and banana, but none gain needed depth.  Very, very sweet.  An immediate dumptruck load of honey-covered biscuits gets dumped upon your tongue, followed by an off-kilter, caramel-and-sweet-corn middle.   The fade holds things together long enough to resemble Hawaiian sweet bread, but this finish isnt worth the initial whirl of flavors.  Smooth and silky, but too sweet for repeat consumption.  (6/9/09)

Bottle @ home, courtesy of LeopoldStoch. Huge thanks! Slightly cloudy, lighter yellow-orange apperance with a fairly small, thick white head. Quite sweet pale to caramel malty bock nose thats slightly bready but quickly appetizing. Thick, pale bock flavor thats somewhat citrusy and creamy with a sweet lager finish. Somewhat bready flavor and mouth feel. Good one.

Bottle - hazy dark yellow/ amber color. Aromas of malt are strong including hints of doughy bread, weathered hay. Smooth and easily drinkable with flavors of malt, spice and slight sweetness. Havent had a lot of this type of beer, but if this is a good representation, I need to search out some more. Good brew.

Pours a hazy gold. Beautiful aroma, bread, spice, and caramel. Light to medium body, with a frothy mouthfeel. Nice carbonation. Subtle hop finish. This beer screams to be paired with a pork dish. Another knock out from smuttynose.

I feel that if the Teutonics were drinking this beer at the time, we would be missing an entire chapter of world history. This beer is so full of malt, and balanced  so nicely with hops and with such an earthy aroma that if I were a Teutonic in the early times, I would sit out the Crusades under a German Poplar tree with a few of these 22 ouncers from Smuttynose in the company of a local milkmaid. The beer itself is a hazy amber with a nice head. The taste is a hair sweet but lets not get into nerd details; this beer is a winner and to heck with the politics of the Crusades.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, slight spice, slight nuts, light noble hops, light bread, and grains.  Poured amber/gold in color with a small to medium-sized, creamy, dense, off-white head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is light to medium to medium sweet and slightly to lightly bitter.  Tastes much like it smells, with notes of malt, slight spice, noble hops, slight honey, grains, slight bread, and some Pils-like flavors.  Medium body.  Tingly, then lightly dry texture is a tad thin.  Average carbonation.  Malt, grain, noble hop, slight honey, slight bread finish is lightly dry.  7.7%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Hay and creamed corn nose. Clear amber, thick head. Sweet untoasted malt, hay, and creamed corn flavor. Finishes drier, with just a light grassy bitterness. This was dreadful and not an extremely old bottle. Unlike most breweries, I prefer Smuttynoses standard offerings to their premium series. This is another example of one of their special beers gone wrong.

Pours dark gold with an ample creamy head. Scent reveals notes of malt and honey. Mouth is smooth and thick. Malt and clover sweetness offset by flowery bitterness that is quick at the end. The higher alcohol content comes through and there is a lingering honey malt sweetness.

Pours a large, yellowish foamy head and a Copper body. Light carbonation with small bubbles. Almost a spicy saison-like aroma with some sweet caramel malt hints. Nice thick sweet bready and caramel malt flavor- smooth, warm doughy malts as well with an underlying herbal and floral hop character. Very smooth mouth feel and palate with a clean doughy malt finish. Really nice. Thanx again goes out to D. Kurts

This bottle was about 6 months old at the time of this review.
Pours a slightly cloudy golden color with a great looking head that laced the glass all the way down. Smells of malt. Caramel, a bit of bread, some faint hops in the background. Tastes sweet, but not cloying, properly sweet for the style. Melanoid malts, caramel, some fruit. Tastes great. Ample carbonation, medium to heavy body. Another great brew from Smuttynose.

Enjoyed from a 22oz bomber in a wine glass.  The beer pours a copper/medium brown color, with a smallish white head.  The nose shows Germanic Munich and CaraMunich malt character.  As the bottle had been aged for some time, hop character had essentially totally dropped out of the aroma.  The palate gives an extremely pleasing note of residual continental character malt sweetness; supported by a crackery underlying pilsner malt character, and just enough carbonation to lift the flavors off the palate; allowing the sample to remain highly drinkable.  A noticeable-if-light hop bitterness does come in; falling short of balancing the malt, but adding complexity and keeping the beer from being too sweet for the style.  The finish leaves a very pleasant note of residual sweetness on the palate.  Overall, a excellent version of the style, and a steal, for the price.
Bottled. A golden beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw as well as hints of spices. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, spices, hops, and straw. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

Bomber shared by Rastacouere.
Appearance : Light hazy yellow with a medium head.

Aroma : Great malt and spices. Light yeast.

Taste : Spices and malt. Spicy and malty finish. Slightly mineral. Light sweetness. Awesome finish.

Overall : Very clean stuff. Very tasty and drinkable. Very well balanced.

Bomber from Half Time. Pours dark burnished brass with a creamy 3 finger beige head. Muted aromas of lightly bready and mild fruit. Med body. Flavor is rather malty with a lot of light stone fruit. Finishes sort of peach pit bitter. Its a really good drink.

A: Pours a deep gold with a bit of an orange tint to it. Off-white head.

S: Nice, but nothing too special. Mostly just a deep breadiness. Bits of caramel and graham cracker.

T: Pretty much straight grain, with a tad bit of caramel and graham cracker sweetness. Tad bit of hop bitterness without much flavor. Fairly one-dimensional, but well done.

M: Medium bodied with good carbonation and not much of any alcohol taste.

D: Pretty nice. Not my favorite of the style, but one of Smuttys better beers.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2010

Bouteille de 22 oz, merci David! Arômes très mielleux et maltés, légère touche de houblon floral. Robe dorée et trouble, peu de mousse et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, les malts clairs sont particulièrement bien développés, apportant des notes de miel, de sucre dorge et de biscuits. Légère touche fruitée dabricot et de houblon floral. Finale légèrement amère et alcoolisée. Lalcool est dailleurs peut-être un peu trop présent en finale. Très intéressant.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2010 The worlds #1 heller bock/maibock, and it was not a disappointment!  Interesting to look at the list - almost all the top ratings went to American releases.  Cant the Germans make a good maibock anymore?  Old European drawing on the label - typical eccentric touch from Smutty.  Superb sweet honey and floral aroma.  Dark gold pour.  A sweet, fruity, and bready brew.  It has a lot of grain and hop character to stand up to the compote flavors.  Unlike some other maibocks I have tried, this really tastes like a bock.  Excellent - one of the best things I have tried from this brewery .

Bomber pours deep clear gold with off white head. The aroma is bold and sweet with slightly peppery caramel apples, plum flavored cotton candy and some mild yeasty spices. The taste is full and near brash in flavor with apples, plums, figs and caramel with a thin edge of peppery boozy harshness. The flavors fade midway and then out into the finish.
A big, heavy clear golden brew with fine carbonation and a fluffy white head. Heavy spice-malt-grapefruit aromas and flavors. Bready and hoppy finish. Smooth and drinkable.

Bottle. Bready hop aroma. Cloudy golden colour. Big stable tan head. The flavour starts off quite alcoholic. It is quite malty with a bit of semi-aromatic hop. Distinct bitterness, quite clean. Good mouthfeel. Like a good German Maibock, but a bit on the alcoholic side.
Bottle. Candied yeast, alcohol aroma.  Golden body with medium head.  Flavor of sweet malts, yeast and hops.  Long sweet and spicy finish. A tasty maibock
Brown and very malty color this is a wonderful malty brew that has good hops and is great to drink on a fall day

This poured an orange color with a moderate white head. The aroma contains lemons, biscuits, and a bit of alcohol. The flavor is malty with some lemons, spices, and some alcohol showing through. Overall this was a very good beer

Bottle.  Pours a dark golden with a medium off white head and some good lacing.  Aroma and flavor are very malty, bready, caramel, a touch of spice, some hoppiness in the finish.  Flavorful and malty.

Pours a clear amber with a decent white head - about average, but acceptable. Aroma is strong and mainly fruity, with a malty undertone and a hint of caramel. Malty flavor has a firm fruity component, mainly pear and banana, with a touch of caramel and quite an alcohol nip, as well as a whisper of honey sweetness. Texture is slickly smooth with just a little tingle, and leaves an edgy finish.

Somewhat light color, but its the aroma and the taste that was so much bubblegum that stood out.  It had bubblegum flavor, but wasnt a wheat beer, and then it was a bit sweet with that. Overall, a nice beer to finish the night with.
A very full bodied Maibock, but I think a lot of belgian.  sweet, slightly cloudy Golden with fair head but not much lacing and with alcoholic notes and yeasty tastes.  Nice clean finsih.

Smuttynose Maibock is a lively, hazy, light golden lager with a creamy, off white head that has great retention and leaves thick lacing.  It smells malty-- a little sweet and bready or pretzely.  Its medium bodied and very smooth with a pretty crisp finish.  It tastes pretzely and peppery.  Its a little fruity and a little wooden.  Theres no sweetness.  The alcohol is certainly apparent in the taste.  There is an odd phenolic note.  This is not something I would really drink on purpose.  I used most of the bottle for a marinade.
Clear golden with a fluffy white head.  Earthy citrus and caramel aroma and taste with vanilla notes to the finish.
Pours amber with an off white head. Has a malty aroma of caramel, toffee, and bread. Nice rich malty flavor with a low hop profile.
6/19/10.  On tap.  Malty aroma with a touch of booze.  The flavor is creamy and malty with plenty of caramel. Not bad.

This one threw me for a loop in a bad way.  I thought I knew what this style was about but maybe not.  Smells of straw and strong vegitation dominate.  Really light in color and body, reminds me of a pale ale color but with less substantial mouthfeel than that even.  The flavors were of raw, dirty grains, again a rotting vegitation that wouldnt quit and than a ill placed artificial sweetness that just didnt fit anywhere.  I got this from a phenomenol store that I doubt mishandled it.   Weird weird weird all the way around.  Thanks Smuttynose.  2010 12oz.
Pours a wonderful golden hue with a nice bright white head that sticks around, and laces nicely.  NIce spicy aromas.  Initial carbonated attack which fades to a slightly sweet finish.  Very nice.

Pale color, white head.  The aroma is malty, bread.  The flavor is bread, molasses, light alcohol.  The finish is sweet alcohol, resin and pine hops.  The body is medium, the mouthfeel has a lot of carbonation.  Decent, good for this style.

A: A very nice looking pour on this one. A vibrant orange color with a fluffy white head and some mild lacing.

S: There is a nice bready malt character to the beer up front along with a light floral hoppiness. A bit of citrus and herbs as well.

T: A surprising sweetness to the flavor with plenty of caramel, bread, and maybe a bit of floral honey. Light citrus and even more floral character.

M: This seems to be right in the middle of the road in terms of body with plentiful carbonation.

D: Definitely on the bigger end of the maibock spectrum (but I suppose thats to be expected from a beer in the "Big Beer Series"). That said, a good beer, but nothing overly exciting.

Bomber via trade.  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a well-formed white head and good lacing.  Aroma is dominated by bready malts with some honey, earth, and light fruitiness.  Flavor is pretty interesting.  Pale malt is the main component, but there are some tropical fruit notes, honey, and maybe even a little oak as well.  Slight hops noticeable.  Very smooth on the palate with medium body.  A solid example of the style overall.  I liked it more than the others at the tasting did.
Deep gold with white head and lace. Light caramel malt and apricots. Sweet caramel malt with a hint of perfume and a decent finishing bitter. Medium bodied but just a tad fizzy.

Bomber.  Pours a darkish gold with little head and honey sweet aromas.  Flavor is fairly sweet, with lots of honey, a little bit of an apple juice presence, some grass and a little metal.  Pretty good stuff, and the style always makes me happy, but it wont get tremendously high marks
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Tap at Pony Bar. Pours hazy gold with a medium, pure white head. Lots of light, sweet malts on the nose, some hints of fruitiness. Flavor is immensely sweet and malty. Also has more fruit, citrus notes. Very mild bitterness. Medium in body, well carbonated, a bit syrupy. Not too bad, but super sugary.
Gold pour with frothy white head. Scent is malts and fruit. Taste is malty and hoppy with a sweet dry finish.

Giant, doughy biscuit malts characterize the flavor, while the bottle-conditioning and tiny (but present) hops give the nose a tiny bit of quasi-Belgian funk. Overall, this fine beer is as good as a maibock can get.
Almost a banana yellowish pour in the glass. Nose is grass, floral citrus. Taste is dough, grass and floral malt. Rated 5/5/04

Sampled at tasting at stevos. Pours cloudy gold with whitish head. The aroma is diacetyl, some light toast, and a little bit of zest. The flavor is lemon bars, Wonderbread, slight diacetyl, and a sweet leafy finish. Its alright, but not my cup of tea.
decaturstevos stevofest part 2.  Sample from a bottle thanks to decaturstevo.  Pale yellow, white cover.  Toasty dry grassy aroma.  Taste is toast, bread, grassy finish.
Raw aroma smelled like a fresh mash tun.  Made me want to make brew up a beer instantaneously.  Cloudy appearance, good mouthfeel with a malty taste.  I would definitely drink again.

22 oz. bottle via trade with smith4498- thanks again, Jason!  Pours a cloudy orange, lighter at the bottom and darker at the top, where the glass is wider.  One-finger off-white head.  Aroma of honey, caramel malts, straw, grains, cereal, apricot, tangerine, and candi sugar.  Flavor of caramel malts, honey, straw, apricot, candi sugar, yeast, alcohol, and funk.  Really sweet.  Medium-bodied, with a sticky mouthfeel and lingering sugary sweet finish.  Im not entirely familiar with this style, only had a couple, but this is super sweet but also pretty good.  If the sweetness could be toned down, Id be interested to see what that would be like.  Definitely worth every penny, for an interesting beer.

2007: Nice looking hazy -- but sunny -- light orange color. Large puffy white head. Lots of carbonation. Looks light and thirst-quenching. 

Rich, sweet malty smell. Has a honey-coated sweet scent. Small bit of Belgian pungency. Also a bitter malty German bite. Very complex. Impressive. Hint of oak and woody hops. 

Thick and strong. Has a very interesting blend of the Belgian sour and the German bitter. Quite a good combination, actually. Both flavors arm wrestle to a draw. Very strong alcohol presence. 

Feels thick and bubbly. Leaves a strong BelGerman hybrid film. Strong and quite drinkable for a 22oz, but ones the limit.

If youre not into pumpkin ales, there are other fall drinking options for you. Of course, Octoberfests are the go-to for many people, but Im not typically a big Octoberfest drinker. This, on the other hand, is a great option. Yet another home run from the Smuttynose Big Beer Series, the Maibock is labelled as a "robust seasonal lager," and that it is. Spicy, extremely malty, earthy, and outstanding, this is a great beer, though far from my favorite in the series. Hats off to Smuttynose.

22 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Golden orange pour with a fluffy and bubbly white head.  Aroma of caramel sweetness, some tangerine citurs hops, and just a bit of graham cracker.  Flavor is a unique blend of hops and caramel sweetness (as least unique within the realm of what I traditionally think of when it comes to a maibock).  The finish is satisfying but short in terms of a lingering flavor.  There isnt too much sweetness.  I really like this one quite a bit.  This was a surprise the first time I had it a while back (before I was rating beers) but I found it just as good this go round.
Pours a soft orange/brown. Smooth and a bit chewy. Roasty flavor, toffee syrup and hugely sweet. Finishes with some bitter and alcohol. Almost too candy-like but still good.

Poured from a 22oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a hazy orange/gold with about a finger and half of white foamy head and some nice lacing.

The smell is hoppy with some earthy flavor. Hints of lemon and grapefruit.

The taste is sweet with a nice fruity flavor coming right out at first with a bitterness that comes in later from the hops and mixes in. A really great spiciness is present as well on the way down.

The feel of this beer is more on the light side and reminds me of a really good summer beer or any time. It goes down well and leaves no aftertaste.

Bottle: &nbsp Dirty straw, quite dark and hazy, large foamy off-white head, sticky lacing. &nbsp Soft bready nose, smells a little bright, minor floral notes. &nbsp Bready on the tongue, a little raw, has some bite, a little 

astringency. &nbsp However, its quite smooth and it certainly feels quite meaty, big for a Helles Bock at least. &nbsp An otherwise dull style, or one that I think is really meant for sessions, has turned into one that is much more 

malty and certainly bigger. &nbsp Not your average Bock. &nbsp Very minor alcohol, moreso in the nose during the backside. &nbsp Seems wheaty to some extent. &nbsp Yeah, definitely bigger than your average, and yes, very malty! &nbsp 

Does become a little mealy as it warms. &nbsp Bigger than expected, and certainly more enjoyable. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp Thanks Brian for the bottle!

On tap at Coles.  Orange-gold with a small white head.  Malty aroma with a little gingerale.  Flavour is appropriately malty, with bread, tart apples and a little hops as well.  Oily, medium to full  body.  Not a favourite style, but Id go back to this one.
Pours orange with an off-white head and some lacing. Taste is a nice balance of hops, sweetness with honey, caramel, and pepper notes. Very good.

I liked the body on this even though it was a bit big for a heller. Sweetness, some honey and light bitterness. Flavor has a bit of alcohol and hops with some mellow spice and pepper with the caramel finish.

22oz Bottle. Aroma is subtle, with a waft of honeyed cereal and some alcohol. Pours a fuming, brilliant orange-gold, with plenty of lacy and foamy off-white head. Flavor bounces around the room, with hot alcohols, somewhat icky yeast byproducts, a lot of sugar and some hop flavor. Jumbled. Body is a good bit too sticky and for me, the alcohols are much too forward. Way too boozy. Bitterness comes in a form thats a bit metallic and somehow not well accounted for. A little sloppy, overall, lacking the crisp lagering quality I look for this style.

Bottle 650ml.Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, fruity, moderate hoppy, orange, light sugar, light alcohol. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, peppery alcoholic finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090813]

22 oz. bottle via trade with smith4498 - Pours a slightly hazy golden-orangish color with  a one finger thick off white head.  Light lacing.  Has a nice lightly sweetened raw malt aroma.  Very nice.  Flavor is a nice, lightly sweetened malt.  Medium body.  This is a really good beer.  Thanks Jason.
Bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo. Pours cloudy ambar colour with nice foamy head. Nice strong malty sweet aroma. Full bodied sweet malt with noticeable bitter. Lingering aftertaste.

A clear hazelnut color with a small beige head that becomes blotchy.  Fruity and grainy aroma.  Interesting flavors.  Wood flavor,  banana, medicinal, alcohol and a nice mix of hops (especially for the style).  This is a sweet beer.  A malty finish.  This beer is all over the place which, to me, is always a fun drinking experience.  Long lasting aftertaste is spicy hops.

I had heard good things about Smutty but had never tried, now Im looking for more.  Pours  a hazy orangish yellow.  Aroma is malt and hop.  Big frothy head that spilled on my table.  Taste was slightly citrus, slightly malt and slightly hop.   My only complaint is that the hop isnt more prevalent but overall this is a fine beer.

Pours a hazy amber orange color with a 1.5 finger frothy yellowish beige head that slowly fades into a lasting ring that leaves sporadic spots of lace.

Slightly roasted caramel malt aroma with hints of maple and floral hops.

Very quaffable, creamy medium body with a huge roasted malt presence balanced out by a prominent earthy floral hop flavor. Hints of chocolate, caramel, toast, hazelnut and slight alcohol warmth. The bitterness of the hops linger over the sweet malt body into a slightly dry finish.

Pours a bright hazy golden with lots of bubbles and a big head. The aroma is floral anc lightly grainy with a herbal nature and some good honey like malty sweetness. Much of the same can be said about the flavor except to say that it is hoppy. The herbal and honey notes are delicious but this finishes particularly dry for the style, a delicious interpretation of the style.

Bomber bottled in 09. Clear golden color with super head. Thick and rich on the tongue. With my eyes closed, I probably would guess a darker color. Very big malt, with sweetness and phenols. It pushes almost into doppelbock territory. Hops dry it out on the back end. Peppery and a bit boozy as well. Right now this is the top ranked Maibock at RB, but I might have preferred a slightly lighter touch.

Pours slightly cloudy honey with thin white head (looks terribly similar to the IPA).  Smells of a refreshing apricot, passion fruit nectar with some acorn on the side.  A hint of zesty phenol activity, some interesting yeast must have been involved.  Tastes a bit belgian with a mild refreshing aftertaste of fruit salad juice and mild lagerish hops.  bit of syrup feel.  Overall: Interesting, but not amazing, I wouldnt get it again, at least not for a while

Pours hazy dark golden color with white head. Aromas of bread dough and caramel. Moderately sweet caramel flavor with bready malts. Alcohol is slightly noticeable. Medium body with average carbonation.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of TheCheeseMan. Pours a clear deep golden with an off-white head. Aroma of sweet clean malts. Medium body, sweet clean and malty with a somewhat tired mouthfeel. Dry, lightly bitter finish. 130809
Clear brown, nice white head. Nutty, toasty aroma, and the flavor is pretty much the same. Fairly simple, but well made and pretty darn tasty. Nicely dry finish.

Pours clear orange with a small off-white head.  The aroma has lightly toasted malt, doughiness, esters and medicinal licorice like notes.  Medium / full somewhat slick body with lots of gentle carbonation.  The flavor begins with lightly toasted doughy malt, spicy hops and peppery notes.  the finish is very hoppy for the style with spicy and earth traits and some dirtiness and and abv heat.  A nice and interesting take on the style.  Id love to try this a bit fresher.

22oz bomber purchased at McKinnons in Salem, NH - split with BA CheckMate. Pours a light amber slightly hazy body with a good inch of off-white head that slowly dissipates. Smells malty and biscuity, with a fair bit of noble hops (Im guessing hallertau?) put there to balance it out. Definitely a bit hop forward for the style IMO, noble hops giving a citrussy bite to it, with a fair bit of malt, expressing itself as toffee, caramel, biscuit, and a bit of chocolate toward the finish. Fairly clean finish, though not as clean or dry as some lagers. Medium in both mouthfeel and carbonation. Not the quickest drinker around, but the pleasant flavors, the balance of the flavors, and the medium body definitely make one sip invite another. Overall, a very solid beer - not quite what I was expecting but more drinkable than many in the series, not to mention much much better balanced. Nice.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear golden coloured with a medium sized white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and dried fruits with notes of vandies.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, candies, hops and pine needles.
Dry hoppy finish.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is dry wheaty, phenolic and mild spiced. Flavour too is spiced, phenolic and spiced yeasty. Dry phenolic finish. Spiced and wheaty finish.
Clear golden with a medium white head. Sweet malty aroma with fruity and caramel notes. Flavour had malt, caramel and hoppy notes. Finished bitter.

copper pour with a white frothy head. Aroma  of caramel malts, with hints of cherry, vanilla, honey, and a caramelized burnt sugar. Tingly to start lot of sugar malts. middle is a little more bitter citrus. Earthy hoppy finish
Not very impressed. There is a sweet spiciness and a medium body. Not very smooth. Grassy flavor.

22oz Bomber- beautiful creamy head that sticks around nicely, but after that im a bit lost.. just to much going on in this brew flavor wise. it feels like to many flavors thrown together, mixed up and brewed..sometimes I think "less is better" when it comes to certain styles this one especially..to me the smell and taste of belgium style citrus and fruits in this really throws it off..it just doesnt fit in good with a half hoppy half toasty brew.. the alcohol is also not well hidden..For me this ones a little overrated, i think that Rogues dead guy is much better  because its not over gone like Smuttys..
Pours a clear golden with with white head. Aroma of caramel, yeast, corn.  Similar taste. Sweetness leads to hoppy finish. Ok

Pours clear gold with a foamy white head that fades. Aroma is honey and alcohol with cherries. Honey and berries are the most dominant tastes with some bitter citrus. Finishes with slight roast malt and sticky.
Pours a lacing off-white  head a a deep straw colored body.  Smells of sweet corn and clean.  Flavor is creamed corn, crisp, sharp, and clean.  Sweet finish.

The pour is bright golden with a pure white head. The nose is big and grainy with a nice layer of hop aroma. The flavor is just an overly sweet mess what the hell. Cloy, corn, and alcohol. I haven’t looked at the stats for this beer, but it tastes bigger than it needs to be. Full bodied and a bit oily. I don’t think I’m finishing this one.

Bottle conditioned in 2008
April/May 2008:  Smuttynose Maibock has a sweet aroma fillede with fuesels.  Its color is golden copper and the beer is hazy.  There is a thin beige head on top.  This beer is sweet and tastes like malt and corn with an odd floral and hearbal bitterness that is difficult to describe.  This beer is VERY floral with some toasted malt and dry-roasted peanut.  It has a medium body and aseems a bit overcarbonated for the style.  Overall this is just an OK beer at best.

22 fl. oz. bottle.  Rating #226 for this beer.

22oz bomber. Pours golden with slight orange hue and medium-sized white head. The aroma is grainy and malty with a nice bit of sweetness and a subtle perfumy noble hop quality. The flavor is malty and delicate - a touch of grainy pilsener malt and a nice balancing punch of noble hops in the finish - distinctly "pilsener" bitterness (like hallertauer or saaz?). The finish is medium - balanced between dry and full - with a nice lingering combo of grainy malts and that wonderful bitterness. The mouthfeel is full and nicely carbonated. It feels luscious - like the big-ass European lager that it is. Overall, pretty nice and very good considering the hot weather we had here today. A pleasure to drink - a very nice example of a maibock.
Bottle.  Pours a golden body with a white head.  Sweet bread y candy sweetness, a hint of cherry honey and caramel.  My favorite Maibock at one time.

Neutral gold color with the slightest of haze.  Long lasting head that leaves good spotty lace.

Malty with a notable level of alcohol warmth in the smell.

Strong alcohol flavor--lots of oily liquor; very warm to the throat.  Lots of lighter malt flavor with nearly no hop bitterness.  This is a dry bock.  Excellent body; truly perfect for the style.

Draft at the Blue Mermaid in Portsmouth, NH. Clear red-amber with a creamy quarter-inch of lasting foam. Sweet grain, peach, caramel, and a hint of toasted nut on the nose. Same flavors with just enough spicy-grassy hop on the finish. Medium body is smooth, lightly tingly and sticky.

Bottle Clear golden lager with a huge, fluffy, white head. Fantastic retention. The nose is a tantalizing blend of peppery hops, toffee and a hint of menthol. Medium to full-bodied with a lightly creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. The flavor provides sweet honey, toffee and caramel - balanced a bit by spicy hops. The finish is bittersweet, although the bitterness lingers longer than the sweetness. Pretty good take on the style. Thanks to scraff for shipping this beer to me!

Athens, Ga. - Five Points Bottle Shop - 22 oz bomber. Pours a slightly murky light orange with a silky white head. Sweet, bready aroma, hints of kids vitamins and yeast. Flavor is sweet as well with some sweet raw cake mix, subtle raisins, some white grapes. Mouthfeel is sticky enough. Solid bock.

clear light orange, thick white foam.
mild malty aroma, with apple, pear, some pine, and a bit of brown sugar. a bit sweet.
thin texture, and a bit flat.
flavor is very pineapple-y, but a bit artificial-tasting, with a fairly bitter finish.
this is nice and refreshing, but the flavor is maybe just a bit off.

Pleasant doughy aroma, with some apricot and vinegar.   Misty, maplewood color, thin ringing head.  Bomber.  Average label. Bitter, boozy, some off flavors, grassy overtones.  Spritzy carbonation, but fairly heavy-bodied, alcohol finish.  Meh.  Market Square Liquors.

Aroma is floral and zesty, heavy on the malts, with corn and grainy notes. Appearance is golden-orange and pours with a quick fading fizzy head. A lot of bubbles surfacing but hardly any head at all remaining on top. Flavors are sweet and malty with apricot and peachy fruits, caramel, and a little zip in the finish. After just a few sips this became too sweet and sticky, almost to the point of being unpleasant and hard to drink. I love Smutty but I wasnt a fan of this one

22 oz bottle. Pours a coppery orange color with a small off white head. Nose is light caramel with some apricot and peach type flavors. Palate is the standard smutty thickness with a nice clean velvety feeling. Flavors are apricot and peach and some light caramel and some sugary sweetness.

22 oz bomber from Spirits Red Bank. Pours a hazy orange/amber with an average to slightly large bubbly mostly white head. Aroma is slightly fruity, notes of green apple and not quite ripe bananas, and lots of grainy malts with a slight touch of bubblegum as well. Thick full syrupy bodied with strong carbonation. Flavor is grainy malts, spicey...perhaps pepper and coriander, yeast. This one was just too dry and spicey when I needed something more cool and refreshing.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow color with a small, foamy off white head. The aroma is sweet with caramel malts up front followed by a touch of spices and floral hops. The flavor follows the sweet theme with toasted caramel up front and joined by coriander, ginger, and other spices. Medium to full bodied, smooth with subtle carbonation. Not bad, but maybe a touch too sweet.
A very tasty and smooth Maibock.  Nice malty balance with great flavor.  Pours light golden with a short head.
Pours a golden color with a thin white head.  The aroma is faint, but it is yeasty and a little fruity.  Taste is sweet maltiness, some yeast, and some dark fruit.  Mild taste overall.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 Old gold pour with a tight healthy foam.  Spicy nose of ripe peach, malt, and hops.  Very smooth palate feel, nice bock flavor.  All malt with no signs of canned sweetness. Tobbaco laden hops dominate for complexity. Finishes with a clean hop bitterness that exudes the European dryness that seeems to define the brewerys style.

Bottle from Brother Tuckers.  Pours an apricot color.  Aroma is fruity and malty.  I get tropical frutis all over the place and some yeasty notes.  Flavor is yeasty, malty, not as fruity as the nose.  I get some sweetness and light bitterness as well.  Not bad at all.

From the 22oz "big beer" series, this one poured a hazy orange with a nice thick white head.  Aroma of tropical fruit, hops, malt and some caramel.  Taste was a refreshing hoppy, citrusy, floral combination that pleasantly suprised me.  Carbonation was just right without being too much.  Nice beer.

A great chewy, fruity flavor- like a hafe mixed with mango and passion fruit juices. Well not really, but tits in there somewhere. This is great fun, very pleasing and will make you not want to share the bomber with anyone else.Flavor disspates quickly, tho. Bottle at Brother Tuckers in Pompano, Florida

Bottle courtesy of hellbilly.  Pours a cloudy orange color with a few chunks and a chunky head.  Aroma of grain, light sweet malt, and grassy and citrus hops.  Flavor of malt, earth yeast and a good hoppy finish.  Wow, I really enjoyed this brew.  Thanks Josh!

Hazy orange pour with a nice, white head. Nice hops spring from the aroma. Citrusy taste, with some light hops involved. Lighter then I expected, but it tastes really, really good. This is definitely a beer I could drink a lot of. Very good balance.

has a strong flavor of canned corn with a touch of citrus hops. the malts and mouth feel are pretty full. taste has a strong alcohol flavor. the rest works well but the corn is what makes this from being outstanding.

The aroma has creamed corn, fruit, and citrus hops. The appearance is nice with a large head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is thin but smooth. Overall a drinkable beer but it has problems.

Bottle.  Sweet malty aroma.  Beautiful golden body, nice sized white head.   Taste is surprisingly mild.  Lightly toasty, some caramel and fruit, not overly sweet.  Sweetness, although fortunately never cloying, develops a little more in the finish, along with a touch of bitterness.   I was looking forward with great anticipation to this Smuttynose offering, but honestly it left me just a tad disappointed.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Sweet malts on the nose, sweet bread, traces of spicy hops in the nose.  Pours a cloudy golden color with a thick white head.  Smooth malty flavor with a lot of spicy notes, finishes somewhat crisp (could have a little more bit in the end).  A little bit too heavy for a maibock in my opinion but still a solid beer.

The bomber was artfully labeled, evoking memories of renaissance era Europe.  The beer came out golden deep yellow with a good stream of carbonation, but a small to nonexistent head.  The smell was malty and yeasty, with some floral hops.  The taste is where it all came together, as the malts, hops, and yeast proved to be in great balance.  The honey like sweetness was pitted against an earthy and drying yeast flavor and spiced up with restrained but noticeable noble hops.  The mouthfeel was a lot fuller than most of the Maibocks Ive ever had, but it was not so full that it went out of style and became a Dopplebock.  The carbonation was quite evident in the mouth.  This was a wonderfully drinkable beer without having to be watered down.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy, medium orange color with a thick beige head.  Tons of lacing.  Earthy aroma with caramel malt and yeast notes.  Flavor has a nice mixture of spices to go with the malt and yeast tastes.  Pleasant and long lasting aftertaste.  Slight hop bitterness in the finish.

2008 Bomber.  Poured clear light-medium orange with a tall, thicker cap of eggshell head.  The aroma picked up toasty leafy notes over an aged caramel and pale malt base.. complementary accents of grassy and fruity hops.. well-presented.  The flavor had slightly tacky aged caramel at the core with dry leafy, grassy, and citrusy bitterness all around.. quite hoppy for a maibock, but it worked well.. finished long, toasty, and bitter.  Thick, rolling carbonation moved this very well across the palate.. bitterness circled the mouth and rode out the rewarding finish.. excellent beer!

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2011 bomber from 07...

hazy burnt orange color with a huge off white head. it is cavernous, wispy and leaves behind lots of splotchy lacing. 

this smells quite sweet and grainy... notes of honey, cooked barley, orange, mint/eucalyptus and vanilla as it sits. 

the palate is on the sweet side and becomes a bit tiresome as time goes on... seems to lack balance.  theres plenty of yeasty richness along with flavors of grain, vanilla, orange, dry grass and a light spiciness on the finish. 

the medium body  leaves a sugar coating on the teeth. it seems to fall flat on the tongue as it warms....

im going to guess that this is really well balanced and tasty... when it is fresh.  7/4/6/3/15/3.5
 09 bottle 1/8/11... lots of orange. hops are very present and seem to clean up a somewhat thick body. vanilla and grain richness are balanced well with spicy and drying hops. 7/4/7/4/15/3.7

Nice haze orange in color. With a nice fluffy head on top that doesnt fade away quickly. Looks VERY good. A not so pungent sweet malt aroma. Sugary aroma. Havent seen this in a heller bock before. If it was more pungent I would have given it a higher score. Nice sweet sugary taste. Nice bitter hop at the end that doesnt last long but makes an impression. A very good beer indeed! Awesome flavor. Biggest thing about this beeer is the sweet flavor. Slight yeast flavor added in to compliment the sweet sugar flavor. Cheers!

22oz bottle.  dark gold/orange under a small white head.   a great pleasantly sweet, sugary, malty, yeasty, aroma.  flavors of honey, butter, lightly toasted malt, and bit of hoppy bitterness for a clean refreshing  finish.  malt dominated.  medium-full bodied.  excellent.

Tap at the Mexican Food Factory. Pours out a clear orange color with a small white head. Aroma is of cloves, sweet fruits, nut, apple cider,  spice and a slight bitterness. Taste is complex and well balanced. Fruity up front with some apple notes, clove, yeast, bubblegum and some earthy nutty notes in there too, all before a slight bitterness on the finish. Very solid, Im usually not a fan of malty stuff, but this was quite good.

22oz bottle.  Vintage 2009.  Clear orange color, white bubbly head.  Aroma of sugary bubble gum.  Nice rich malts, hint of toast.  Followed in aroma with a clean, crisp herbal hop.  Heavenly aroma.  Flavor is a stick sweet malt nectar.  So good!  Big and chewy.  Some ripe tree fruits as well like a juicy apple.  This beer is so damn tasty.  I am definitely gonna have to buy more of these.  Sweet enough it should age very well.
Bomber 07 vintage. Pour is orange/amber with a thick white head. Aromas of spice, earthy hops, sweet fruits, and citrus. Flavor is much of them same and really drinkable. Nice and well worth $2.99.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text:
22oz 2008 bomber courtesy of Dyan, thanks for the opportunity. The color of this beer is orange and has an odd brightness to it. It smells yeasty, cloves, malty. The flavors I get are fruits like apples and fruit with acidity. I am sure fans of the style will like this but my palate is still unable to really appreciate lagers.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-23-2008 01:29:45

Bottle acquired via trade with blipp.  Pours a filtered copper color from the bomber with a malty off-white head and mild carbonation.  Smells of yeast, juicy grapes, and gym sock.  Features the flavors of underripe strawberries, white grapes, red apples, sourdough, and plenty of malt.  Builds in character as you drink it, but I would not recommend handling a bottle on your lonesome, as there is an element of pumpkin pie spice that grows tiresome.

Bomber...received from a trade with Oteyj.....orange amber with a beige head......smells like a nut bread...yeast and bread notes followed by pecans and almonds along with some sweet malts...medium sweet body, with a sour bitter mixed finish....aroma is not as prevalent in the flavor...its more sweet malt and spices (cinnamon and nutmeg)...pretty good...mild bitter and dry finish---orange rind taste tinged throughout

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 Bottle 650 ml.
Appearance: clear amber lager with large, frisky, creamy-white top.3+
Aroma: sweet, fruity, berry like with slight peppery hop side. 
Flavour/Palate: full bodied, slightly oily in texture. You will be welcomed by alcohol warmth right from first sip. Thick, malty body supports well its formula. Malt it self is candy sweet but with out crossing cloying point. Good bock.

Bomber from Phhd.  Thanks Ethan.  Shared first beer of election night.  Pours light orange with a bright white head.  Nose is sweet and malty.  Taste is sweet malty and biscuitty.  Taste and drinkable.

Draught sample at the Portsmouth restaurant.  Not really my area of expertise or even experience.  Aroma and flavour seemed buttery and I swear I tasted watermelon in the finish.  Not my typical style so not much to say other than it was easy drinking.
22 oz. bottle - pours dark orange and clear; white head lingers; mild carbonation; musky aromas of caramel, orange peels, dank fruit; drinks dry with fruity finish; pretty tasty
Draft at the Other Room.  Poured a nice bown. Some head. Malt and hops, not quite as hearty as I’d like it but pretty decent.
Nice orange amber color with this one. Found this to be very sweet, almost tot he point of detracting from it. But the little fruitiness in there kept this enjoyable for a pretty long slow bottle.

2008 Flour City Brew Fest. Amber pour with a huge white head, big malt aroma. Malty flavor with a proper amount of hops to balance it out, almost dry finish. A little thin on the mouth feel, but other wise great.
Light amber pour with fluffy off-white head.  Leave a decent lace behind.  Toasty/nutty aroma. Caramel malts, grain, and some fruit

22 oz. bottle from Once Upon a Vine McArthur in Richmond. Slightly hazy reddish brown pour with a small head. Sweet grainy and slightly nutty aroma. Taste is grain, caramel and spice. I got some paper notes initially, but those faded. Thick texture.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear light amber color with a small creamy white head.  The aroma is moderately sweet malt with hints of fruits but not much else.  The flavor has some off flavors that I think are associated with hops.  The malt component is lacking here.  Some fruitiness and mild sweetness.  I don’t think this is a good example of a maibock.  I’ll pass the next time.

(From 8-3-08 sampling- thanks to whoever brought it!) Hazy orange in appearance, medium carbonation, aroma of oranges, bread, and musk.  Hits the mouth with a medium body, malt seemed to be very slightly toasted, some mild sweetness in the middle, finish that lingers with a slight hop note.  Good stuff maynard!

Bottle in trade from rbuckstar. Thanks man!
Pours a rich butter caramel color with a small head.  Smell is toasty, tart, almost nutty malt.  Taste is nice and refreshing but with crisp, tart maltiness.  Biscuity and bready and very nice and flavorful.  Good body and solid carbonation.  Easily my favorite of this style, and one I would enjoy trying again.

Amber hue with decent big bubble head; patchwork of odd shaped lacings left on the glass.  Yeasty and fruity/bready malt aroma.  Slightly peppery/earthy hops noticeable upon taste.  Soft mouthfeel.  Cleaner than most yeasty beers.  Nice Summer seasonal.

The pour reveals a clear orange amber color with a thin white head. Very nice aroma of fruits, malt and some sweetness. The flavor has a great fruity, malty presence with some hops and restrained sweetness. The body is medium with an oily texture and gentle carbonation. This is easily the best maibock I’ve had so far.
22 oz bomber.  Pours a cloudy golden orange with a medium sized white head.   Aroma of honey, light wheat and malt.  Taste of honey malt with a bit of wheat.
Light malt aroma with a mild amount of yeast. Clear light orange color with a medium white head. Sweet beginning with a slight bitterness forming in the finish.

Bottle 08’.  Amber pour with nice bone white head.  Nice hop spice and baked goods flavor.  Sweet and well balanced.  Perfect carb and medium body.  I shared this with some friends who are not beer fans and they enjoyed it.  Really well done brew.

Bottle. 2008 vintage. Pretty orange-amber. Tall fluffy white head. Aroma is caramel, honey, spicy and floral hops and soft grassy notes. Some bready notes as well. Taste is grassy and floral with spicy hops, caramel, dark bread, soft yeast and honey. Some buttery notes too. Gets sweet in spots but then has some herbal and floral notes coming through. Maybe a buttered and honeyed biscuit with flowery hops could describe this. Body is medium to medium-full with a strong creamy carbonation. The end brings more bread, caramel, honey, butter, soft fruit, sweet malts, grass and spicy hops.  Tasty beer!

Bottle (2008). Pours deep orange/gold with a huge peach colored head. Aroma is clean sweet malt with honey and caramel dominating, accompanied by bready and earthy notes. The body is smooth. Flavor is sweet malt, again, honey, caramel, and bread. Also has a light yeasty, earthy, and even fruity side to it. I get a bit of peach and citrus. Very nice.

A hazy light amber with gorgeous creamy head and lace. Big aroma of elegant sweet, fresh malt, hint of honey, subtle fruit and spicy hops. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, tons of malty goodness, smooth, toasty (someone mentioned hints of smokiness and I did perceive that as well)  with hints of fruit, clean as hell. Spicy/earthy hop and yeast bite. A treat!

Hazy burnt orange color.  hoppy, sweet, and spicy complexion.  hints of caramel, citrus, and a touch of sour find there way on to the tongue.  soft citrusy feel with decent carbonation.  very enjoyable beverage!

The color was yellow/orange.  The head was thin, creamy, and white.  The aroma was alcohol, hops, and caramel malt.  The flavor was alcohol, hops, sweet, and spice.  The palate was well carbonated.  The finish was warm.

Pours a hazy copper amber with a creamy orangeish  two finger head. Lively carbonation. The nose is nice and hoppy, sweet, earthy, malty, caramel, lagering shows in the nose. The flavor has a nice hop bite to it, a little citrusy, earthy, malty, sweet, caramel. Nice biting palate with a refreshing carbonation. Easily the best maibock Ive ever had.

5/6/08 notes:  had on tap.  Pours a light amber-red.  Little aroma detectable, just some malt and light cherry/strawberry.  This beer starts a soft caramel sweet with some hops, and finishes a light, sour, grassy flavor.  Great soft and chewy palate.  Finish is interesting in that it is slightly sour.  Very drinkable and refreshingly different.  3.6

Mostly clear dark golden color with a thin even loose white head.  Slight spicy and herbal grainy aroma with a touch of earthy hop character.  Light taste over a thickish palate.  Tastes a bit spicy with a light pine hoppiness informing the finish.  Grainy malts carry everything well.  A refreshing bock.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 My Bottom Line:
Soothing floral, herbal hoppiness is perfectly levelled with honeyed cereals in a come-hither mouthfeel where earthy yeast and herbal hop bitterness encourage you to take an even greater sip. This is as authentic a Bock as you can find in North America.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A lingering cloud of foam garnishes the hazy amber.
-Balance is achieved throughout.
-Such authenticity and quality makes me wish theyd brew a Pilsener now!
-The frothy bubbling and healthy mouthfeel are pleasant all the way.
-Alcohol never shows in the flavor profile; this is as drinkable as any other unfiltered lager.
-Close to a year-old, it reveals nice biscuity, caramelized sugars. It changes but does not tire, it seems. A nice evolution. 

Bottles; 2008, 2009 and 2011 vintage.

In short: An extra-refreshing juicy maibock.  Excellent execution in simplicity
How: Bottle 22oz, fresh.  on the Stone-Bourbon-Barrel-RIS-Hype-And-Disappointment tasting session with the Montreal crew 
The look: Cloudy orange body with a medium white head
In long: Lots of grainy cereals, light caramel and soft honey, citrus and orange juice and fresh grass.  A light tartness.  Lively carbonation and very pleasant mouthfeel.  Wow!  Nothing fancy, but this is an extra-refreshing strong lager that can be enjoyed by the full pint, and many of them.  An unexpected surprise to me.  Coming into this tasting I never thought a Smuttynose Lager would come out on top of the Stone Bourbon Barrel RIS.  Thats like a piss-drunk hare beating a hare on speed in a screwed-up psychedelic La Fontaines Fable.  Now what the fuck am I talking about?!?!

22 oz.  Golden orange pour with a fine cream colored head.  Good lacing.  Clean toasty nose, light hops - weird chardonnay type component.  Great fresh flavor.  Tangerine, lemon candy, stone fruit.  Smooth bitter finish.  Doughy?  A nice beer, one that I could session (dangerously) around the BBQ or at the beach.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2009 Pours a murky orange amber with no head.  Smells of malt and caramel and honey.  Flavor of alcohol and orange rind. Medium full body, low carbonation.  Light bitter finish.  Not bad.  Syrupy sweet with honey.  Good for the style I suppose, but not my favorite.

Pours a bright, slightly hazy golden amber with a dense one finger head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving no lacing.  The smell is wonderfully sweet with caramel malts, apples, yeast and some very mild citrus hops.  First taste is of the super sweet sugar which gives way to the malt background before finishing with the citrus hops.  There are also some spices present in the finish.  Its medium bodied and smooth with good carbonation, almost syrupy, but not quite.  This is one of the better Maibocks Ive had and Im once again impressed by a Smuttynose brew.  Nice!

Bottle from shigadeyo. Clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate roasted malt aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and lively carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.
22 oz bomber, 2008 edition. Pours a hazy gold color with a 1/2" head. Nose is malts, yeast & pine. Flavor is a nice balance of malt & hops with a slight belgian yeasty flavor, spicey.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2009 hazy golden pour, off white, healthy head.  
malt assault in the nose, spicy.  sweet malts,  faint hops noticeable and appropriate. alcohol is present but not unpleasant, very warming.  Flavors of sweet candy malt and burnt sugars, some  dough. finish is warming and sticky..MMm its spring time and smuttynose is there to welcome it in.

Man, I thought I rated this - thanks to my better half for sharing this, then - lightly hazy golden beer, with a sticky, soapy, lasting head - the aroma is peppery and zesty up front, but some floral character and a honey sweetness develop underneath that, along with some earthy hops - a tad bit sweet at first - honey almost overwhelms the palate, but a lightly bitter herbal and floral flavor comes up from behind that, followed by spicy hops, and eventually, some alcohol warmth that lasts through the finish, so the overall sensation of drinking the beer is of a progressive warming feeling - if I were a more poetic and sappy person, Id say this reminds me on the gradual coming of spring - but I am not that kind of person, so thankfully I would never put something that silly in a beer rating.

Bottle acquired via trade with jjpm74...thanks John!!!  Although the nose lacks intense aroma (just a slight underwhelming sweetness), visually this beer is stunning.  Hazy 14 karat with an amazing 2-inch head that leaves significant lacing on the glass.  Flavor is highly malted...with candied sugar, honey, and caramel on the tongue.  The 7.7% isnt noticeable and the hops find their way in the finish.  A pretty solid beer by Smuttynose.

On tap at Track 84 in Warwick, RI.  Cloudy gold color with a medium white head.  Aroma of hops, apples, and honey.  Very refreshing beer with a nice combination of sweet and tart with a noticeable but not overpowering hop finish.  Tastes like Spring.  Very nice beer!

1 pint 6 fl. oz (US) Big Botle series. 2008 recipe.  Pours copper in color with a generous off-white, creamy head.  Aroma of yeast, alcohol, and some hops. Medium mouth feel.  Tastes more sour than sweet.  It is kind of bitter but noit like a traditional bitter brew.  The hops are not overpowering but I can tell they are there.

Tap at Mugs Ale House: Pours an orange/golden with a small but strong white head. Decent aroma of soft German malts, a hint of citrus and a subtle hop note. Creamy body with a solid malt bite. Has a very light honey sweetness along with balancing herbal hop hints and a grainy character. A solid Bock.
A very solid maibock, nice light body that you kind of expect out of this kind of beer with sweetness and a good deal of alcohol burn.  Yum.

Bottle. Hazy cloudy gold color with medium sized fizzy head. Aroma of sweet malt,light caramel, bisquet dough, and hops. The taste was the same but rich, big, and chewy. Sweet and too thick so refreash you on a nice spring day, but enjoyable never the less.

Near cloudy dark golden to amber colored liquid. Taller, somewhat fluffy vanilla milk colored head. Dried flower, biscuits, raisin scone and light cream caramel aromas. Maibock does not come to mind. Some apricot pits also seem to be present in the scent as I try to figure this one out. Light sweet flavors in the front with light caramel and lightly toasted malt and clover honey. Middle has a return of dried flower and wintergreen hops. Not as clean as I like my maibocks, but the flavors are malty with just enough hops to make things interesting.

Pours a cloudy golden-orange color with a dense, foamy, off-white head.  Sticky clumps of lacing cling to the glass.  The nose is sweet and toasty up front, with a good deal of caramel providing the malt base.  Spicy, floral overtones and a touch of fresh ginger complete the nose.  The flavor is again very sweet, falling on the saccharine side of balanced.  Toasty caramel is joined by wildflowers, ginger, coriander, and various other spices.  A substantial, syrupy body finishes pretty clean, but sits heavy on the stomach.  Overall, a very solid example of a style Im not really crazy about.  Nice beer.

22oz bottle pours a hazy color of peaches and cantaloupe.  Moderately thick, full, chewy, upright and solid on the palate, with a sweet fruitiness and and a mild but noticeable twang that seems to lighten the entire experience and give the drinking session liveliness.  Fresh, sticky, frothy, delicious stuff.  Nowhere near a true maibock but pretty good for whatever sort of hybrid style it actually is.

bomber of 2007 vintage. Pours a cloudy orange with a decent white head. The nose is malty heavy and slightly resinous with hints of toast, toffee, cherries, and just a pinch of sharp hops. Mouthfeel is moderately dense and pleasingly coating. I find a few similarities here to a barleywine. Something about the sweet, brown sugar flavor and vinous qualities. . .Modest suggestions at a German lager are made and intertwine oddly well with the fruity, dense malt character. Very, very nice interpretation of this style.

Cold 22oz bottle:  Pours an egg yolk orange color with minimal alabaster bubbles around edges.  Aroma is of light, sweet grains and cherries with earth notes.  Taste:  starts and ends malty sweet with a crescendo of earthy bitterness that remains predominant throughout.  Crisp and effervescent.  Somewhat soapy aftertaste with some alcohol burn.

22oz bottle, 2008 vintage. fresh bottle sampled. pours hazy golden with foamy white head. aroma is leathery, hint of citrus and biscuity. leathery hop flavors coating the tongue while a good dose of bitterness balances the biscuity clean malt profile. medium sticky body makes this not as sessionable as id want but this is a great maibock.
2007 Bottle. Pours clear orange with a thick creamy white head. Possibly the most powerful honey aroma I have ever smelled. Flavor of honey, molasses, and caramel. Hides its alcohol well. Nice.

Pours a nice medium gold with a tall foamy white head. Aroma is of honey and yeast with a few floral hops. Initial taste is a very smooth light honey and spicey, maybe peppery, flavor.The finish is reminiscent of a Belgian yeast mixed with some of those same floral hops. Overall its a very good and smooth beer.

Bottle. Aroma gives off spices at first, hops come into play with the spices and put me in a meadow, and then the meadow starts to grow some apricots. Flavor similar, spices and hops/spicy hops, caramel malt shows through more. Doesnt have me jumping out of my seat, but I cant find a single thing wrong with it either.

Bottle.  Pours a light amber with small white head.  Aroma and flavor strongly of floral and citrus hops, also some spices and molasses.  This reminded me of an american pale ale, actually.  I thought the hops and malt flavors blended really well together.  An excellent beer!

Pours hazy amber with lasting two finger beige head and great lacing. Nose of apricot, orange peel, lemon grass, overall citrus, caramel malt, and yeast. Flavor was much the same- with molasses and caramel evident from the residual sugar. Nice lingering spicy hop bite. mouthfeel was rich and smooth- surprisingly so for a beer this light. Lots of flavor packed into an excellently balanced package- definite winner.

courtesy of oteyj. nice bubbly head, great lacing. beer is a hazy amber coloration. aroma of orange peel, spice, and yeast. flavor is complex- starts very smooth, then an intense flavor of sweet molasses and a hoppy finish. mouthfeel is nice, my first heller bock and I liked it a lot, really nice beer.
Pours bright gold into a shaker. Bright white head quickly recedes to skim surface leaving no lacing. Sweet malt aromas.  Crisp caramel upfront with a lasting hop and alcohol finish.

Very nice brew! Mild aroma. Good fine head with lots of lace. The color is a golden yellow despite the commercial description. Mouth pleasing body. Just enough hops and carbonation to offset the sweetness. Great finish. Easy session beer. Having thls at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse where it was just put on draft.

July 2007 - Golden orange color, smallish head and ok lacing.  Sweet bready musty malt aroma.  Flavor was of sweet breadreally sweet.  Some hops were present.  Oka little too sweet and syrupy to be refreshing and enjoyable.

Pours a dark gold with a big off-white head that sticks around well. 

Doughy malt, herbal notes, banana, light floral hops on the nose. 

Toasty but not burnt malt taste up front, grassy and floral hops bring up the rear. Yeasty banana-like notes. A bit of spice and booze. 

Medium bodied, good amount of carbonation. Alcohol is at times distracting but evens out into a nice balance the longer it stays in the glass.

Crystal clear coloured golden body with a thinnish white head. Aroma of fresh malt, strong fresh hops and a potent lemony scent - even though this is a bit aged, it still smells fresh! Medium-bodied; Strong malty flavour with toffee and caramel notes following behind. Aftertaste shows a nice hoppy kick tucked into a astringent finish. Overall, a very nice and refreshing beer altogether! Definitely worth trying if you can find it anywhere! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Olivers Beverage in Albany, New York on 11-December-2007.

Great thick and hearty beer. Very pale tasting heller bock. The malts were very subdued by the hops, but it was a welcomed unbalanced because the hops were very citrusy, almost like a well done IPA with much more maltyness. Beautiful orange color with orange head.
Solid beer here. Poured a nice golden color with a huge head good lacing.  Aroma was grassy and honey.  Flavor was a perfect blend of grassy hops and sweet malts.  Refreshing beer well done.

Almost clear, rich gold, small white head, adequate lacing.  Honey, sweet malts, and yeast.  Taste is too bready, too yeasty, to grassy, too floral for my preferences, and there is just a tad too much alcohol.  Close, but it just doesnt work.  If I wanted that much bread and yeast Id go with a less sweet Belgian saison or tripel.

Bottle sampled. Pours a cloudy orange with a off-white head. Aroma of light citrus, caramel, honey, bread, and pale malts. Flavor is full bodied and smooth with caramel, citrus, mellow malts and some spices with a dry bitter finish
Amber pour with a huge white head, big malt aroma. Malty flavor with a proper amount of hops to balance it out, almost dry finish. I love it. a  touch thin on the mouth feel, but other wise great.

Appearance: Pours a cheery-looking orange body with a small, white head.

Smell: An aroma filled with honey and spice and everything nice (i.e., dough and lemon). 

Taste: Light, sweetish caramel flavor with notes of bee-fresh honey and citrus fruits. Noticeable doughiness. Hop flavor and bitterness remain quite light. Wraps up with a very drying finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-body. Medium carbonation. Somewhat sticky mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Works for me! A pretty good maibock.

Golden orange in colour, long lasting off-white coloured head, good lacing.  The aroma is floral, some must, yeast, some light sourness, fruits - mainly apples.  The flavour is of citrus, floral and herbal hops, quite spicy, noticable alcohol.  Moderately hot mouthfeel, medium body, high carbonation.  Finishes long, sweet, some spice, hot.  Its okay in a weird sort of way, didnt really grow on me.
650ml bottle from the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York for $4.99.
Purchased on August 20, 2007 and opened on August 28, 2007.
Bottled in 2007.

[2007 bottle] Pours a barely hazy gold color, with some great lacing. Dense malt aroma, some honey sweetness. A total malt-bomb of flavors, with some interesting yeast character and subtle hop bitterness. Full bodied, with slight alcohol warmth through the finish.

Bottle courtesy of Sammy: Poured a cloudy deep beige/orangey color ale with a huge foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of semi-sweet malt is dominant. Taste is a mix between some dry malt with some light sweetness and some light nutty notes. Body is full with some limited filtration with great carbonation. There was a dryness in this beer that I didnt particularly enjoyed but otherwise it was a fine example of the style.

Wow, is this good.  Though I love this style, too often I get renditions which are too hot and have this annoying monolithic malt profile.  Here, the malt is not overly heavy--it shows a lot of nuance--and there is real hop character in the finish.  Beautifully balanced.

Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Appearance: hazy gold, fine white head, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: sweet yeast bread aroma with munich and caramel malts and earthy hops
Flavor: sweet sourdough bread flavor, candy caramel sweetness, light earthy balance
